item.title: French queen consort's gold-plated heart rescued from thieves
item.description: The priceless 16th-century casket containing Anne of Brittany's embalmed heart was stolen earlier this month, fuelling fears it could be melted down.

media:group.media:description: The priceless 16th century casket was located buried, but safe. (Supplied: Dennis Jarvis)

item.title: Knife-licking killer sentenced to at least 20 years in jail
item.description: A woman who stabbed her flatmate eight times before licking his blood from the murder weapon and saying "now you see what I'm capable of", is jailed for at least 20 years in South Australia.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Opie

media:group.media:description: Leanne Carol Prak received a mandatory life sentence. (Supplied: Channel 9)

item.title: Disability charity manager stole $1m to fund pokies habit and holidays, court hears
item.description: A Queensland woman is jailed for eight years for syphoning $1 million from a respite centre for disabled youths over a number of years, in a crime a judge called "calculated and callous".
item.dc:creator: Tim Swanston

media:group.media:description: The long-time charity worker spent about $2,500 a week on poker machines. (ABC News: Julie Hornsey)

item.title: George HW Bush hospitalised with blood infection after wife's funeral
item.description: Former US president George HW Bush was admitted to hospital the day after his wife's funeral, where attendees included George W Bush, Bill and Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama and current First Lady Melania Trump.

media:group.media:description: George HW Bush is pushed by his son at Barabra Bush's funeral just days before the former US president was hospitalised. (AP: David J Phillip)

item.title: Owner charged after Labrador-border collie killed in axe attack
item.description: A man from the WA coastal town of Esperance is charged with animal cruelty over allegations he killed his two year-old Labrador-border collie cross dog with an axe.
item.dc:creator: Graeme Powell

media:group.media:description: Axe in Wood (brittgow, Flickr.com)

item.title: From Alice to the Arctic: The challenges of shooting a story in extreme cold
item.description: Alice Springs-based journalist Stephen Schubert is used to battling heat exhaustion and dehydration but it was hypothermia and frostbite he faced on assignment in Norway to report on the Doomsday Vault.
item.dc:creator: Steven Schubert

media:group.media:description: Steven Schubert trudges through sleet while on assignment in Svalbard, Norway. (Supplied: Cathy Reade)

item.title: Inflation pulse still weak, up 1.9 per cent and still below RBA comfort zone
item.description: Australia's inflation rate stays stuck below the RBA's 2-to-3 per cent, despite expectations it would start to accelerate in the March quarter.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Letts

media:group.media:description: Food inflation remains low rising by just 0.5 per cent over the past 12 months. (ABC News: Raveen Hunjan)

item.title: Bogut rules out NBA return, commits to Kings for long term
item.description: Sydney Kings unveil their star signing on Tuesday morning, with Andrew Bogut committing to a two-year deal and declaring himself retired from the NBA.

media:group.media:description: Bogut says he won't be back in the NBA or take up offers from Europe. (AAP: Tracey Nearmy/File)

item.title: Luxury rooms, golf and, er, palliative care unit? Big plans for $100m resort
item.description: A palliative care unit isn't where you expect to go on vacation, but the developers of a planned $100 million resort on Tasmania's east coast say there's a market in China for somewhere to go that's "peaceful and quiet".

media:group.media:description: The heritage-listed 1830s homestead could become a wedding venue under the plan. (Supplied: Roberts Real Estate)

item.title: Scandal-plagued live export ship gains approval to carry sheep
item.description: Maritime authorities approve the Awassi Express, the vessel linked to thousands of sheep deaths in the Middle East, to again carry livestock.
item.dc:creator: Brett Worthington

media:group.media:description: (News Video)

item.title: Australian surfer dies in Bali in wipeout that snapped board
item.description: Wollongong man Jae Haydon, 35, dies after surfing reportedly "giant waves" near Uluwatu — a well-known break. His broken board washed up on a nearby beach late yesterday.

media:group.media:description: Jae Haydon sings a song near the Harbour Bridge. (Supplied: Dean Snushall Photography)

item.title: 'Sickheads': Lesbian couple targeted with hateful note, find car tyre punctured
item.description: A same-sex couple living with two children north of Brisbane find their car tyre punctured and a note calling "lesbianism an abhorrent practice". Now they're encouraging anyone else targeted in the same way to notify police.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Williams

media:group.media:description: The note found on the couple's car outside their home north of Brisbane. (Facebook)

item.title: 'Tremendous energy, tremendous intellect': Trump's trusted choice is one step closer to confirmation
item.description: Mike Pompeo's path to Secretary of State is clear now he has narrowly avoided a historic rebuke by the US Senate Foreign Relations Committee. But that's just the start: he'll inherit a department with plunging morale, writes Charles Edel.

media:group.media:description: Mike Pompeo, appearing before a Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has a clearer path to confirmation now. (Reuters: Leah Mills)

item.title: Hunt continues for suspected Mossad agents after killing of Hamas engineer
item.description: Malaysian police say they are still hunting "two light-skinned suspects who are European or Middle Eastern" after a the assassination of a Hamas engineer suspected to have been working on weaponised drones.
item.dc:creator: Norman Hermant

media:group.media:description: Inspector general Mohamed Fuzi Harun said the suspects appeared to be "European or Middle Eastern". (AP Photo)

item.title: Perth is wetter than Melbourne, Hobart and London, and it's all because of the type of rain
item.description: Perth may be best known for its idyllic beaches and sunny skies, but the WA capital actually sees more rain than other cities often associated with gloomy, wet weather.
item.dc:creator: Irena Ceranic

media:group.media:description: Perth has fewer wet days per year, but when the rain does fall, the city often cops it. (ABC News: David Weber)

item.title: Anger as Snapchat video shows teens' raid on Anzac memorial
item.description: A group of young people film themselves stealing wreaths and flowers that had been placed by schoolchildren at an Anzac memorial in Melbourne's east.
item.dc:creator: Zalika Rizmal

media:group.media:description: The wreaths were trashed and left on the ground in the park. (Supplied)

item.title: Indonesian police bust fake Rohingya people-smuggling network with AFP help
item.description: Indonesian police say they have worked with the AFP to unravel a people-smuggling network that was aimed at bringing in fake Rohingya refugees to Australia.
item.dc:creator: Adam Harvey

media:group.media:description: People smugglers are taking advantage of the plight of legitimate Rohingya refugees fleeing persecution by boat. (Reuters)

item.title: Corals build 'cloud umbrellas' to protect themselves from scorching sun
item.description: Australian researchers find corals build "cloud umbrellas" to help keep cool and their decline could have wider implications for climate and agricultural production.
item.dc:creator: Sharnie Kim

media:group.media:description: Researchers say it may be possible to create cloud cover for corals by spraying sea salt into the air. (Supplied: Griffith University)

item.title: Where to go to pay your respects in Brisbane this Anzac Day
item.description: Here's everything you need to know if you plan on attending the dawn service or Anzac Day parade in Brisbane on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Williams

media:group.media:description: A soldier stands guard during an Anzac Day dawn service at the Cenotaph in Brisbane. (AAP: Dan Peled)

item.title: Live: NAB adviser forged customer initials on official documents, commission hears
item.description: National Australia Bank is the focus of the banking royal commission this morning, with senior executive Andrew Hagger under pressure to explain improper conduct by some of its financial advisers, including forged initials on documents.
item.dc:creator: Michael Janda

media:group.media:description: NAB's chief customer officer Andrew Hagger answers questions about financial adviser misconduct. (Supplied: Royal Commission)

item.title: Who made the first Anzac biscuit?
item.description: Most family recipes tell a story, but none so much, or with as much mystery still surrounding it, as the Anzac biscuit.
item.dc:creator: Eloise Fuss

media:group.media:description: Few can resist a tasty Anzac biscuit. (ABC News: Daniel Battley)

item.title: Australian hospitals failing to meet rising demand for obesity care, experts say
item.description: Australia's public hospital system is not adequately resourced to treat the 1 million adults who currently live with clinically severe obesity, a new study has found.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Willis

media:group.media:description: Obesity is one of the leading contributors to disease in Australia. (Pixabay)

item.title: Pauline Hanson says company tax cuts she supports wouldn't deliver higher wages
item.description: The One Nation leader concedes "I've never said that there will be an increase in wages" under the company tax cuts bill, for which her party has pledged conditional support. Executives from some of Australia's largest businesses are facing a Senate grilling about their lobbying for the cuts.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Doran

media:group.media:description: Pauline Hanson says she has never claimed there would be an increase in wages. (ABC News: Nick Haggarty)

item.title: Her father was labelled an enemy of Australia, but this WWII veteran was given 'a very secret job'
item.description: At just 18 years of age, Chinese-Australian Kathleen Quan Mane joined the Air Force as a codebreaker — despite her father being treated as a "foreigner and enemy" and her mother's citizenship having been revoked.
item.dc:creator: Samuel Yang

media:group.media:description: Kathleen Quan Mane was one of the first Chinese-Australian women to join the war effort. (ABC News: Samuel Yang)

item.title: 'They come in here broken': The recovery centre putting soldiers back together again
item.description: Rifleman Brett Humphrey is only 26 years old, but despite being fit and able-bodied, he suffers from epilepsy and can't return to his old job. That's where the Soldier Recovery Centre steps in.
item.dc:creator: Tom Maddocks

media:group.media:description: The Soldier Recovery Centre is focused on recovery and rehabilitation. (ABC News: Dane Hirst)

item.title: Burton-Higgins clash revives AFL bump debate
item.description: Opinion is divided over whether Hawthorn defender Ryan Burton should have been charged for the bump that concussed North Melbourne's Shaun Higgins.

media:group.media:description: The bump by Hawthorn's Ryan Burton (L) on North Melbourne's Shaun Higgins has highlighted confusion over AFL rules on legal and illegal contact. (AAP: Julian Smith)

item.title: Waffle House shooting suspect arrested as history of mental health issues is revealed
item.description: The man suspected of killing four people at a Nashville restaurant allegedly used an AR-15 rifle that had previously been seized amid mental health concerns.

media:group.media:description: Travis Reinking is suspected of opening fire on restaurant patrons. (AP: Metro Nashville Police Department)

item.title: Google profit jumps 73pc on soaring online ads, after Wall Street slips
item.description: As the busiest week of US reporting season begins, Google reports a bumper profit based on a surge in online ad revenue, but Wall Street ended down.
item.dc:creator: David Chau

media:group.media:description: After releasing its quarterly profit figures, Google stocks surged for 5 minutes before plunging into negative territory. (ABC News: Ben Sveen)

item.title: 'Man drought': The truth about being a single woman after 30
item.description: Did you know there's a "man drought" on? Or that in some places those who don't have a partner are known as "leftover women"? Yep, it's a jungle out there.

media:group.media:description: Jules Gibson in Singled Out documentary (Supplied: Singled Out)

item.title: Archaeologists discover an ancient Vietnamese society
item.description: An accidental pottery find has led archaeologists to uncover evidence of people living on Vietnam's islands more than 3,000 years ago, with a WA historian saying the discovery was made by chance after one of his team members had a flat tyre.
item.dc:creator: Laura Meachim

media:group.media:description: The Vietnam Maritime Archaeology Project discovered ancient artefacts estimated to be 3,000 years old. (Supplied: Vietnam Maritime Archaeology Project)

item.title: Women to lead Darwin's Anzac Day march for first time
item.description: Darwin's 95-year-old Anzac Day march will be led by women veterans for the first time on Wednesday, when the Women Veterans Network NT guide about 150 returned service people through the Darwin cenotaph.
item.dc:creator: Elias Clure

media:group.media:description: Corporal Sonya Newman lost a leg after years of horror injuries to her leg. (ABC News: Mitchell Woolnough)

item.title: Cream for outback scones could return as new player whips-up rescue package
item.description: Outback cooks will no longer have to serve scones and jam without cream if a new processor's plan to step in to replace the staple Devondale long-life product to remote kitchens comes off.
item.dc:creator: Eric Barker

media:group.media:description: Alby Davey from Chatsworth Station has been experimenting to find a replacement for the Devondale long-life cream. (ABC Rural: Eric Barker)

item.title: Curious Darwin: Why is rent in Darwin so high?
item.description: Would you pay $260 a week for a house with no kitchen? It's far from an anomaly in Darwin. We take a look at what the experts say is behind the high rents.
item.dc:creator: Emily JB Smith

media:group.media:description: At one point, agents had more than 10 prospective tenants bidding on a single property. (ABC News: Nic MacBean)

item.title: Ron Medich: The millionaire with Sydney in the palm of his hand
item.description: Millionaire property developer Medich rubbed shoulders with the powerful, even bribing them with prostitutes, but paid the ultimate price for his ruthless and seedy method of business involving an execution-style murder.
item.dc:creator: Riley Stuart

media:group.media:description: Ron Medich was found guilty of murdering a business foe. (AAP: Brendan Esposito)

item.title: Health of platypus habitat trumps development on city's outskirts
item.description: Residents on the rural outskirts of Brisbane fight back against advancing housing developments that could put platypus populations under pressure.
item.dc:creator: Hailey Renault

media:group.media:description: Little is known about how many platypus live in waterways around south-east Queensland. (ABC Open contributor Bollygum)

item.title: It's time we got a personal income tax cut — here's why
item.description: Australians are facing rising living costs but wages aren't keeping up. A cut to personal income tax would help, while injecting more spending money into the economy, writes Saul Eslake.

media:group.media:description: Australians are facing rising living costs but wages aren't keeping up. (ABC News: Jessica Hinchliffe)

item.title: Penis transplant for US Afghanistan veteran
item.description: A former serviceman who was injured in an explosion in Afghanistan says he is recovering well after a highly experimental transplant last month that involved a 14-hour operation by Johns Hopkins University doctors.

media:group.media:description: The medical team that carried out the penis transplant at Johns Hopkins University. (Supplied: Johns Hopkins Medicine)

item.title: American submariners honoured in special Brisbane dawn service
item.description: For three years during World War II, Brisbane's New Farm Wharf hosted thousands of Yankee submariners. Their legacy is honoured at a relatively new dawn service at the wharf that is getting bigger every year.
item.dc:creator: Tim Swanston

media:group.media:description: The USS S-42 was one of the first to arrive in Brisbane and was based in New Farm Wharf while patrolling through the war. (Supplied)

item.title: My mother, the Soviet spy
item.description: In the early 1930s, a pregnant Chana Salman was jailed for her links to the 4th Department, a Red Army espionage ring. Her daughter and granddaughter are digging into the past to find out why she risked everything to become a spy.

media:group.media:description: Chana Salman was arrested for espionage. (Supplied: Archives de la Prefecture de Police (France), 19940474/9.)

item.title: Tonnes of Tasmanian tyres headed for approved local recycling centre
item.description: It's been a 16-year process from inception to approval, but Tasmania will finally have a local solution to a massive tyre stockpile, with a recycling plant being approved in Launceston.

media:group.media:description: The stockpile at Longford contains just under a million tyres. (ABC News: Damian McIntyre)

item.title: Outspoken firefighters' union boss challenged for top job
item.description: Unionist Peter Marshall, who led Victoria's firefighters into political warfare with the Premier, is facing a threat to his position from a rival who has signalled his support for Daniel Andrews.
item.dc:creator: Richard Willingham

media:group.media:description: Peter Marshall (L) will run against Lyndon Clarke (R) for state secretary of the union. (ABC News/Supplied)

item.title: Australian taxpayers' millions handed to Chinese-owned gas company
item.description: The Federal Government awards a $6 million grant to a gas producer wholly owned by a massive Chinese company said to have close links to the country's Communist Party.
item.dc:creator: Mark Willacy And Alexandra Blucher

media:group.media:description: President of Landbridge Group with China's President Xi Jinping in Australia in 2014. (Supplied: Landbridge)

item.title: The AFL's Anzac Day clash is a great tradition, but share it around to make it better
item.description: The AFL's Anzac Day match is one of the game's special occasions, but giving every club the chance to play on April 25 and making it a standalone commemoration would enhance the tradition, writes Richard Hinds.
item.dc:creator: Richard Hinds

media:group.media:description: Bombers players make their way from the ground after the round 5 AFL match between the Collingwood Magpies and the Essendon Bombers at the MCG in Melbourne, Monday, April 25, 2016. (AAP: Julian Smith)

item.title: Giving life back to a people who have no hope
item.description: Ray Martin goes inside a refugee camp in Bangladesh where an estimated 50,000 people are blind. Australia's Fred Hollows Foundation is trying to change that.

media:group.media:description: Cataract surgery is carried out on 500 eyes a week in the camp. (ABC News: Ray Martin)

item.title: Imams shouldn't be judge, jury and relationship counsellor for marriages
item.description: The problem with Islamic divorces in Australia is a symptom of a deep, structural malaise in many of our "mainstream" religious institutions: a tendency towards old-school, patriarchal cultural conservatism, write Omar Hashmi and Mariam Tokhi.

media:group.media:description: Islamic scriptures clearly afford both men and women the right to divorce. (ABC News: Briana Shepherd)

item.title: We benefit from modern slavery every day, but there's new hope for workers
item.description: While the concept of slavery may seem remote, we often unwittingly benefit via the clothes we buy, the food we eat and the companies we invest in, writes Justine Nolan.

media:group.media:description: Rashida Begum, who survived from the rubble of collapsed Rana Plaza Building plays with her daugther (Reuters: Andrew Biraj)

item.title: How to make sense of contradictory health news
item.description: It seems like every day there's a new piece of health advice in the news that contradicts the advice we got yesterday. So here are seven litmus tests to help you sort science from pseudoscience.
item.dc:creator: Tegan Taylor

media:group.media:description: Wait, are carrots good this week because they're rich in vitamin A or bad because they're 'full of carbs'? (Getty: Westend61)

item.title: Virus related to HIV dates back 9,000 years, still affecting thousands of Australians
item.description: A highly carcinogenic virus affecting thousands of Australians and dating back 9,000 years, needs to have a coordinated public health response, researchers say.
item.dc:creator: Bridget Brennan

media:group.media:description: The amount of virus that is in someone's blood is critical to determining what the risk of disease is. (ABC News: Tom Hancock)

item.title: 'It looked deliberate': At least 10 dead, 15 injured after van hits crowd in Toronto
item.description: Witnesses say the driver of a rental van that slammed into people on a busy Toronto footpath appeared to make no effort to stop but officials say it is too soon to determine if the incident was an act of terrorism.

media:group.media:description: A woman reacts after a van mounted the sidewalk, crashing into a crowd of pedestrians in Toronto. (AP: Nathan Denette/The Canadian Press)

item.title: The Australian birds and mammals 'more likely than not' to become extinct
item.description: For the first time, researchers calculate the risk Australian birds and mammals will not survive the next 20 years on Earth. One bird's chance of extinction is approaching 100 per cent.
item.dc:creator: Michael Slezak

media:group.media:description: The King Island brown thornbill is the most endangered bird in Australia, according to new research. (ABC News: Adrian Boyle)

item.title: When mum and daughter are both on the autism spectrum
item.description: Most people tend to think of autism as a disorder that affects boys and men, but psychologists now believe that girls with autism may simply be better at hiding in plain sight.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Armitage And Barbara Miller

media:group.media:description: Emma Taylor was diagnosed with autism months after her daughter Felicity received her own diagnosis. (ABC News: Barbara Miller)

item.title: Is Australia still the land of the fair go when it comes to the banks?
item.description: Do we really live in an egalitarian society? Amid the revelations from the banking royal commission, Monday night's Q&A panel examine how the banks were allowed to continue taking advantage of the "little people" for so long.

media:group.media:description: A man talks on the phone outside a Commonwealth Bank branch in Melbourne's CBD. (ABC News: Margaret Burin)

item.title: Former police commissioner admits to relationship with target of investigation
item.description: Former Northern Territory police commissioner John McRoberts denies trying to undermine an investigation into travel agent fraud, while admitting to an intimate relationship with its "major target".
item.dc:creator: Felicity James

media:group.media:description: Former NT police commissioner John McRoberts admitted he had been in an intimate relationship with Alexandra Kamitsis. (ABC News: Felicity James)

item.title: William and Kate welcome Royal baby boy, fifth in line to the throne
item.description: Mother and baby are doing well, says Kensington Palace, as the birth of a son for the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge is announced. The boy is the third child for Prince William and Kate, and fifth in line to the throne.

media:group.media:description: Britain's Prince William and Kate, Duchess of Cambridge with their newborn baby son as they leave the Lindo wing at St Mary's Hospital in London London, Monday, April 23, 2018. The Duchess of Cambridge gave birth Monday to a healthy baby boy — a third child for Kate and Prince William and fifth in line to the British throne. (John Stillwell/Pool photo via AP)

item.title: Brisbane author Emily O'Grady wins $20,000 Vogel Literary Award
item.description: Brisbane author Emily O'Grady wins the prestigious $20,000 Vogel Literary Award for her novel, The Yellow House.
item.dc:creator: Alice Matthews

media:group.media:description: Brisbane author Emily O'Grady, winner of the 2018 Vogel Literary prize. (Supplied)

item.title: Accused 'dine-and-dash' woman has significant criminal record, court told
item.description: A woman accused of being one half of Perth's infamous 'dine-and-dash' couple indicates she will plead guilty to eight new charges, as police reveal she has 41 prior convictions for fraud and is likely to face a further 46 charges.
item.dc:creator: Joanna Menagh

media:group.media:description: The police prosecutor said Ms Loder had a significant criminal record including dozens of fraud convictions. (ABC News: John Sambell)

item.title: Record numbers of US Marines arrive in Darwin for six months of joint training
item.description: The largest contingent of US Marines to ever be stationed in the Northern Territory arrives in Darwin to spend the next six months training alongside the Australian Defence Force.

media:group.media:description: The 1,587 US Marines started arriving in the Top End this month. (Supplied: Australian Defence Force)

item.title: Pictures of long lost Australian WWI submarine reveal clues about its fate
item.description: An expedition returns after uncovering new clues about what happened to Australia's first submarine, HMAS AE1.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Hair

media:group.media:description: HMAS AE1 fin and implosion rubble over control room. (Supplied: Paul G.Allen, Find AE1, ANMM, Curtin University, Navigea Ltd)

item.title: Tasmanian Anglican asset sales won't all go to sex abuse victims, Bishop confirms
item.description: Tasmania's Anglican Church confirms it will keep most of the expected $20 million raised from asset sales, with a quarter going to redressing victims of historical child sex abuse.
item.dc:creator: Georgie Burgess

media:group.media:description: St James Anglican Church in Waratah was sold to a private buyer after being deconsecrated in 2013. (Facebook)

item.title: AMP facing threat of shareholder class actions for misleading ASIC
item.description: One of the three law firms investigating on behalf of shareholders says it believes it has the potential to be one of the biggest investor class actions in Australian legal history.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Chalmers

media:group.media:description: AMP Why insurance? (AMP website)

item.title: Paris attacks suspect Abdeslam sentenced to 20 years in prison
item.description: A Belgian judge sentences Salah Abdeslam, the prime surviving suspect in the 2015 Islamic State attacks on Paris, to 20 years in prison over a shootout with police in Brussels in 2016.

media:group.media:description: Twenty-six-year-old Salah Abdeslam, a Frenchman based in Belgium who was the sole terrorist survivor of the Paris attacks. (Supplied: French police)

item.title: Super Netball draws world's best, but questions raised over import policy
item.description: Super Netball's season two gets underway this weekend, in the shadows of Australia's shock Commonwealth Games loss to England and amid a debate over the merits of including international players in the league.
item.dc:creator: Brittany Carter

media:group.media:description: The new Super Netball season is about to start, with the spotlight on a changing of the guard in world netball. (AAP: Peter Rae)

item.title: Australian violin prodigy becomes youngest Menuhin Competition winner
item.description: Ten-year-old violinist Christian Li becomes the youngest winner of one of the world's most prestigious international violin competitions, the Menuhin Competition.

media:group.media:description: (News Video)

item.title: Cafe owner charged with drug trafficking 'boasted' about lifestyle 'incompatible' with income
item.description: ACT police allege one of five men charged over a significant drug trafficking operation in Canberra bragged on social media about a lavish lifestyle that was "incompatible" with his reported income.
item.dc:creator: Elise Pianegonda And Elise Fantin

media:group.media:description: Brendan Leigh Baker, 26, is facing a string of drug trafficking and importation charges. (Facebook)

item.title: Here's why Will and Kate probably can't go full Kanye when they name the new prince
item.description: Prince North? Probably not. The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge will have one eye on tradition when naming their baby, but they might have freedom to cut loose a little.
item.dc:creator: Alle McMahon

media:group.media:description: It's a boy! The Duchess of Cambridge has given birth to a son. (Reuters: Henry Nicholls)

item.title: Sydney man allegedly plotting police station attack returns to jail for internet use
item.description: A man police believe was radicalised in jail and allegedly planned to attack Marrickville Police Station will return to custody for using social media and searching for the location of the NSW police academy and Goulburn jail.
item.dc:creator: Lily Mayers

media:group.media:description: Greg Ceissman used his mother's phone. (Unsplash: Gilles Lambert)

item.title: London Marathon runner dies after collapsing during race
item.description: A chef running in the London Marathon dies after collapsing during the race as thousands of competitors struggle through the event's hottest year on record.

media:group.media:description: A photo of Matt Campbell, 29, a professional chef who died after collapsing during the London Marathon on April 22, 2018. He is pictured holding a finishers medal after running the Manchester Marathon on April 8, 2018. (Instagram: mattsoire)

item.title: Teacher 'emotionally blackmailed' student she encouraged to meet for sex
item.description: A teacher at a prestigious Adelaide school encouraged a student to meet her for sex and emotionally blackmailed him into keeping their relationship secret, the District Court hears.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Opie

media:group.media:description: Former Concordia College teacher Bettina Schmoock (R) pleaded guilty to procuring a child for sexual activity. (ABC News)

item.title: Fans await royal baby announcement as Duchess of Cambridge goes into labour
item.description: The world awaits an announcement of a royal baby after the Duchess of Cambridge is admitted to St Mary's Hospital in London in the early stages of labour.

media:group.media:description: Two supporters of the royal family hold dolls wearing crowns as they stand outside the Lindo Wing of St Mary's Hospital after Britain's Catherine, the Duchess of Cambridge, was admitted after going into labour ahead of the birth of her third child, in London, April 23, 2018. (Reuters: Henry Nicholls)

item.title: Victoria is building a dozen new schools as student numbers explode
item.description: The Andrews Government will build a dozen new schools as part of a $353 million package aimed at catering to an explosion in student numbers in Victoria's growth areas.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Anderson

media:group.media:description: How our schools are changing and what more needs to be done (ABC News)

item.title: NBL the winner after 'icon' Bogut signs with the Kings
item.description: Andrew Bogut's signing is a big coup for the Sydney Kings, but leading Australian basketball figures expect his arrival will benefit the whole league, not just his new club.

media:group.media:description: Andrew Bogut (R) is swapping the high profile of the NBA for a return to Australia with the Sydney Kings. (AP: Winslow Townson, File photo)

item.title: China says 36 dead after tour bus crashes in North Korea
item.description: Thirty-two Chinese tourists and four North Koreans die in a major bus accident in North Korea, China's foreign ministry says, with two Chinese nationals seriously injured.

media:group.media:description: (News Video)

item.title: Housing incentive scheme questioned, with 'awareness campaign' bagged as 'propaganda'
item.description: Almost a fortnight after announcing a financial incentive scheme aimed at curbing the housing crisis, Tasmania's Housing Minister won't say whether anyone has signed up to the program, or what the eligibility criteria is.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Coulter

media:group.media:description: Industry figures say more needs to be known about the program. (Pixabay)

item.title: Myer appoints new CEO to turn department store around
item.description: Embattled retailer Myer announces British veteran retailer John King will be its new chief executive, subject to visa approval.
item.dc:creator: Carrington Clarke

media:group.media:description: Myer chairman Garry Hounsell (right) praised the recruitment of John King (left). (Supplied: Myer)

item.title: The Crown actor breaks silence over pay gap with female co-star
item.description: More than a month after the revelation the actress who plays the Queen in Netflix's acclaimed series The Crown was earning less than her male co-star playing Prince Philip, Matt Smith addresses the pay disparity, saying they should be paid "equally and fairly".

item.title: Removing flogging from public eye in Indonesia's Aceh draws Islamist resistance

item.title: Central Australian Aboriginal sign language shared in Tasmania

item.title: Tasmanian Anglican churches could be sold to fund abuse survivors redress

item.title: Trump doesn't think his personal lawyer Michael Cohen will 'flip' against him

item.title: Woman's death in watch house prompts call for independent probe
item.description: Queensland Police Ethical Standards Command is investigating the death of a 44-year-old Brisbane woman in the Ipswich watch house on Saturday, but prisoner advocate Debbie Kilroy says it is inappropriate for police to investigate themselves.

item.title: Sharks hold off the Panthers after Eels stun Manly

item.title: Teenage pair charged over fatal hit-and-run crash
item.description: A 19-year-old man and a 15-year-old girl are charged with culpable driving and theft of a motor vehicle in connection with a fatal hit-and-run crash involving an allegedly stolen vehicle in Melbourne's east early on Saturday.

item.title: Preserving the 'art of repair' builds sense of community at Alice Springs cafe

item.title: World's oldest person dies in Japan at the age of 117

item.title: Simmons joins elite company with NBA playoffs triple-double

item.title: Barbara Bush remembered as family's 'enforcer'

item.title: Reward offered to find out who killed Melbourne mother of four
item.description: It's been 36 years since Jenny Rose Ng was found by her two young daughters, stabbed to death in her Melbourne flat. Police hunting for the person responsible are now offering a $1 million reward.

item.title: Retired couple capturing a treasure trove of data on Australia's dolphins

item.title: These young Canberrans give up their weekends to make others' safer

item.title: The Ellenbrook train debate is heading down a strangely similar track

item.title: 'Marry first, then fall in love': The evolution of love and marriage in China

item.title: We are made of star stuff. But what does that mean?

item.title: We're starting to give up on the ideal of Australia as a nation of equals
item.description: A very large number of people have come to feel that they are just cogs in a machine — counting for nothing more than their capacity to work and vote. They are angry. They are disappointed. They are vengeful, writes Simon Longstaff.

item.title: Australian Antiques Roadshow spin-off in planning phase
item.description: Famous for unearthing treasures buried in plain sight, the BBC's Antiques Roadshow has inspired British TV presenter Tim Wonnacott to push for a similar series based in South Australia.

media:group.media:description: Council chief executive Mark Goldstone with Tim Wonnacott and Lord Mayor Martin Haese. (Facebook: Martin Haese)

item.title: Police arrest teens over deadly hit-and-run crash in Melbourne
item.description: Two teenagers are arrested in connection with a fatal hit-and-run at in Melbourne's east that resulted in the deaths of a couple, who were driving home.

media:group.media:description: The pair who died were in a car that collided with a stolen four-wheel drive. (ABC News: Nicole Asher)

item.title: Republicans 'disappointed' PM didn't oppose Charles becoming figurehead
item.description: Some British republicans hoped Malcolm Turnbull, a well-known advocate of installing an Australian head of state, would campaign against a Royal being put in the head of Commonwealth role.
item.dc:creator: James Glenday

media:group.media:description: Malcolm Turnbull has been a high-profile advocate of installing an Australian head of state. (AP: Victoria Jones)

item.title: Myanmar police ordered a 'trap' for reporters, court told
item.description: A police captain tells a court that he was told by a superior "if you don't get [journalist] Wa Lone, you will go to jail", while giving evidence about a "set up" to arrest a Reuters reporter.

media:group.media:description: There have been international calls for the release of Wa Lone (pictured) and Kyaw Soe Oo. (AP: Thein Zaw)

item.title: Shark attacks, quokka selfies and when damage control becomes damaging
item.description: The public might rightly hope both major parties in Western Australia come to realise it is fruitless to politicise the issue of shark attacks, because it seems to have a habit of coming back to bite them, writes Jessica Strutt.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Strutt

media:group.media:description: A great white shark and a quokka. (AAP)

item.title: Matildas heartbreak as Australia misses out on women's Asian Cup glory
item.description: Australia falls just short of becoming champions of Asia in men's and women's football after the Matildas suffer a heartbreaking loss to Japan.

media:group.media:description: Emily Van-Egmond's (R) Matildas missed out on the chance to make Australia Asian champions in men's and women's football. (AP: Raad Adayleh)

item.title: Local knowledge critical when waiting for rain in outback Queensland
item.description: When your livelihood depends on the weather, predictions, patterns and planning are paramount, especially for farmers and graziers in western Queensland where families have kept an eye on the skies for decades.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Woodward

media:group.media:description: Baratria Station has rainfall records dating back to 1890. (ABC News: Nicole Bond)

item.title: 'Big progress': Trump hails North Korea's move to stop nuclear and missile tests
item.description: North Korea will suspend nuclear and missile tests effective immediately and abolish a nuclear test site ahead of planned summits with South Korea and the US, with US President Donald Trump tweeting that the announcement is "very good news".

media:group.media:description: A North Korean missile is launched during a test in May last year. (Supplied)

item.title: How one country town is learning to live with dementia
item.description: It was a comment from her boss two years ago that led Jane Parkin on a life-changing investigation. Now, she and her husband are among those in the small town of York on Perth's outskirts who are benefitting from a new approach to dementia.
item.dc:creator: Emily Piesse

media:group.media:description: Laurie and Jane Parkin say York's dementia awareness program has given them reassurance. (ABC News: Emily Piesse)

item.title: School students testing the water in Tasmania for a career in marine biology
item.description: Secondary students from every state and territory are spending their school holidays doing real marine science on Maria Island off Tasmania's east coast, a global hotspot for climate change.
item.dc:creator: Felicity Ogilvie

media:group.media:description: Student snorkelling off Maria Island. (Supplied: UTAS)

item.title: Dave Kok bringing Tasmania to the Shetland Islands
item.description: Transplanted Tasmanian Dave Kok is doing such a comprehensive job of talking up his place of birth to the Scottish locals at his new digs, he jokes he should be receiving a commission from Australian tourism authorities.
item.dc:creator: James Dunlevie

media:group.media:description: Dave Kok is a devoted Western Bulldogs fan. (Brand Tasmania/Magnus News Agency)

item.title: Graves of Darwin's hidden dead possibly beneath roads, houses
item.description: A Darwin cemetery used to house hundreds more graves than it does now — where they are today is a subject of debate.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Thompson

media:group.media:description: Peter Forrest believes unmarked graves may lie beneath modern Darwin. (ABC Radio Darwin: Jesse Thompson)

item.title: The secret tattoos of the ancient Egyptians
item.description: Archaeologists wielding new, sometimes experimental techniques, reveal ancient tattoos — and the medical, spiritual and cultural significance they might have held.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Mitchell

media:group.media:description: Archaeologists were startled to find a tattoo on the shoulder of Gebelein Man. (Supplied: British Museum)

item.title: How to spot a koala when you can't see one
item.description: Conservation relies on data, not dreams, of koalas — but these Australian icons are notoriously hard to spot.
item.dc:creator: Ann Jones

media:group.media:description: Sleepy by day, by night the koalas will be shouting from the tree tops. (ABC Science: Ann Jones)

item.title: What is the Falun Gong movement and does China really harvest organs?
item.description: For years, practitioners of Falun Gong have campaigned on the streets of Australia — but who are they and what are they trying to achieve?
item.dc:creator: Vicky Xiuzhong Xu And Bang Xiao

media:group.media:description: A Falun Gong protest banner reads "stop forced organ harvesting in China" in Hong Kong. (Reuters: Bobby Yip)

item.title: McGowan says she wanted to expose Weinstein as rapist on billboard
item.description: Actress Rose McGowan, who helped trigger the #MeToo movement, says a billboard company refused to take her money when she planned to expose Harvey Weinstein 20 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Steve Cannane

media:group.media:description: Rose McGowan has alleged Harvey Weinstein raped her in a hotel room during the Sundance Film Festival in 1997. (ABC News: David Sciasci)

item.title: $1 a week — that's how much the recycling crisis could cost ratepayers
item.description: Victorian homeowners will ultimately bear the brunt of China's decision to ban foreign waste, with the state's peak local government body estimating ratepayers will be stung an extra $60 a year to cover recycling costs.
item.dc:creator: Danny Tran

media:group.media:description: The Municipal Association of Victoria expects homeowners to pay an extra $60. (ABC News: Matthew Roberts)

item.title: Get on your bicycle and discover Brisbane's best new street art
item.description: There's a way you can see paintings by world-renowned artists this weekend without stepping foot in a gallery or paying an admission fee.
item.dc:creator: Hailey Renault

media:group.media:description: There's more than 20 new street art pieces to see around Brisbane. (Supplied: BSAF)

item.title: 'Hot rod capital' of Australia in photos
item.description: A celebration of hot rods is on show in the central Victorian town of Castlemaine, paying tribute to the people who build them, drive them, and write about them.
item.dc:creator: Larissa Romensky

media:group.media:description: The Father, The Son and The Chev: Laurie Williams (left) and his son Darren Williams. (Supplied: Darron Davies)

item.title: Thousands of US students walk out in protest of gun violence on 19th anniversary of Columbine
item.description: Students from more than 2,600 schools stream out of their classes in the latest round of gun-control activism following the February shooting at a high school in Parkland, Florida.

media:group.media:description: A student attends a rally outside the White House as part of nationwide walk-outs of classes to mark the 19th anniversary since the Columbine High School mass shooting, at Lafayette Park in Washington, DC, US April 20, 2018. (Reuters: Carlos Barria)

item.title: The incredible gift of being the only person in my family who can hear
item.description: Growing up with deaf parents and brothers, Jodee Mundy became the family interpreter and conduit to the mainstream world. Now she's on a mission to preserve their "Deaf culture".
item.dc:creator: Patrick Wood

media:group.media:description: Jodee Mundy is the only person in her family who can hear. (Illustration by Luke King)

item.title: From electroshocks to religious 'cure camps': Survivors share reality of gay conversion therapy
item.description: When Health Minister Greg Hunt refused to condemn political discussions on gay conversion therapy, people who endured such treatments were shocked. They say attempts to 'cure' their same-sex attraction have caused life-long pain.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Hegarty

media:group.media:description: Liam Webb attended a gay conversion camp in the US that he thought would "heal" his sexual orientation. (ABC RN: Siobhan Hegarty)

item.title: Dance music star Avicii found dead in Oman
item.description: Avicii, the Grammy-nominated electronic dance DJ who performed sold-out concerts for feverish fans around the world, dies aged 28.

media:group.media:description: Avicii performs at Pildammsparken in Malmo, Sweden in 2016. (Reuters)

item.title: Crocodile-teasing stunt videos cause safety concerns in Australia's north
item.description: The Western Australia Government is increasing the penalty for feeding or taunting crocodiles to $200,000, saying lives are being put at risk by people videoing stunts like luring crocodiles onto boat ramps or making them jump for food.
item.dc:creator: Erin Parke

media:group.media:description: Feeding crocodiles from boats is allowed in some parts of the Northern Territory, but illegal in Western Australia. (Supplied)

item.title: The royal commission changed this week — from awful and dumb to utterly shocking
item.description: Extraordinary deception. Atrocious behaviour. No concern about consequences. This week's evidence was consequential and now the political environment has shifted, writes Dan Ziffer.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Ziffer

media:group.media:description: AMP chief executive Craig Meller and chairwoman Catherine Brenner at the company's annual general meeting last year. (AAP: David Moir)
